questions.question: 'Religious believers should not use contraception.' Evaluate this statement.
answer: Arguments supporting the statement:
• Catholic Church teaches contraception is wrong as it prevents natural purpose of sex
• Some believe it goes against God's command to 'be fruitful and multiply'
• Natural family planning is seen as acceptable alternative
• Life begins at conception, some contraceptives prevent implantation
Arguments against the statement:
• Many Protestant denominations accept contraception for family planning
• Islamic teaching generally permits contraception within marriage
• Responsible parenthood includes planning family size
• Contraception can protect health and prevent spread of disease
Evaluation:
• Different religious traditions have varying views
• Modern interpretations often more accepting than traditional views
• Personal conscience plays important role in decision
Conclusion:
While some religious groups oppose contraception, many accept it as part of responsible family planning, suggesting the statement is too absolute.
questions.explanation: This question requires detailed knowledge of religious teachings about contraception and the ability to evaluate different viewpoints.

questions.question: Explain how religious believers might respond to the problem of evil and suffering.
questions.topic: Theme C: The existence of God and revelation
answer: 1. Free will defence (2 marks):
• God gave humans free will
• Evil results from human choices
2. Test of faith (2 marks):
• Suffering tests and strengthens faith
• Example of Job in scripture
3. Soul-making (2 marks):
• Suffering helps develop moral character
• Opportunity for spiritual growth
4. Greater good argument (2 marks):
• God has a greater purpose we can't understand
• Evil and suffering serve ultimate divine plan
questions.explanation: This question tests understanding of theological responses to a key philosophical challenge to religious belief.

questions.question: Compare and contrast Islamic and Christian beliefs about life after death.
answer: Similarities (4 marks):
1. Both believe in resurrection of the body (1)
2. Both teach final judgment by God (1)
3. Actions in this life affect afterlife (1)
4. Eternal existence of the soul (1)
Differences (4 marks):
1. Islamic belief in Barzakh vs Christian immediate judgment (1)
2. Different descriptions of paradise/heaven (1)
3. Islamic physical descriptions vs Christian spiritual focus (1)
4. Role of Jesus in Christian judgment vs Allah's direct judgment (1)
questions.explanation: This question tests ability to analyze similarities and differences between religious beliefs.
